fields.headline: This week's new films
fields.bodyText: Beasts Of The Southern Wild (12A) (Benh Zeitlin, 2012, US) Quvenzhané Wallis, Dwight Henry. 93 mins That rarest of things: a genuine, unclassifiable original that seems to have come out of nowhere. It's set in a nowhere time and place, a sort of post-Katrina New Orleans-meets-Kevin Costner's Waterworld, where our six-year-old narrator observes her father's illness and her bayou community's plight with dreamy detachment. It's a film that takes great risks – bare-bones story, non-professional actors, prehistoric creatures, jerky camerawork – but it all pays off beautifully. Ginger & Rosa (12A) (Sally Potter, 2012, UK/Den/Can/Cro) Elle Fanning, Alice Englert, Alessandro Nivola. 90 mins Two 1960s girlfriends come of age in very different ways in this outstanding drama, shadowed by anxieties over the nuclear family and the nuclear threat. Beautifully shot and powerfully acted, it sits neatly between Fish Tank and An Education. Frankenweenie (PG) (Tim Burton, 2012, US) Charlie Tahan, Catherine O'Hara, Winona Ryder. 87 mins Burton takes his retrovision horror fixation out for walkies with a black-and-white, stop-motion tale of a 50s boy and his reanimated dog. It's detailed enough, but hardly a bold leap. Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted (PG) (Eric Darnell, Tom McGrath, Conrad Vernon, 2012, US) Ben Stiller, Chris Rock, Jada Pinkett Smith. 93 mins The zoo animals wash up in Europe and run off with the circus in this latest in-yer-face package, which, depending on your outlook, is either a psychedelic paean to inclusivity or a carbonated sugar-rush of junk-entertainment. 5 Broken Cameras (15) (Emad Burnat, Guy Davidi, 2011, Pal/Isr/Fra/Neth) 94 mins A Palestinian man documents Israeli intrusions on his West Bank village, and the sacrifice of his filming equipment as well as land and life, distilled from years of amateur footage. Inherently biased, it's still a powerful, tragic account. Flying Swords Of Dragon Gate (15) (Tsui Hark, 2012, Chi) Jet Li, Zhou Xun, Chen Kun. 122 mins It's not just swords, everything seems to be flying in this kinetic 3D epic: fists, arrows, people, crockery … A sequel to Hark's classic Dragon Gate Inn, it's a convoluted desert adventure that's really all about the action. The Rolling Stones: Crossfire Hurricane (U) (Brett Morgen, 2012, UK/US) 150 mins The rock legends struggle to tell us something we don't know in this horse's-mouth account of their half-century together. Still, there's archive footage and exclusive access galore. Paranormal Activity 4 (15) (Henry Joost, Ariel Schulman, 2012, US) Katie Featherston, 87 mins The horror franchise continues its steady descent into irrelevance, with more CCTV scares and spooky kids to bring the story on – if anyone's still following it. Student Of The Year (12A) (Karan Johar, 2012, Ind) Siddarth Malhotra, Sana Saeed, 146 mins A new generation of Bollywood hopefuls compete in track, field and love. Out from Friday Sister Social realism at the ski resort in this French family drama. Dark Tide Halle Berry is the bait for this shark-hunting thriller. Out from Mon Hello Quo Status Quo hop on the rock biopic bandwagon. Out from Mon Chakravyuh Incendiary Indian thriller pitting Maoist revolutionaries against the state. Out from Wed Doctor Faustus Marlowe's play as recently staged by London's Globe Theatre. Out from Wed The Penguin King David Attenborough narrates a 3D penguin documentary. Out from Wed Skyfall Bond takes one for the team in Sam Mendes's latest instalment. Elena A Russian wife protects her inheritance in Andrei "The Return" Zvyagintsev's latest. Room 237 A look at Kubrick's The Shining unearths revelations. Stitches Ross Noble plays a vengeful clown in this comedy horror. Welcome Abroad A depressed French painter befriends a teenage runaway. Coming soon In two weeks... Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master … Jacques Audiard's modern love story Rust And Bone … In three weeks … Ben Affleck's cunning Iranian rescue plan in 70s thriller Argo … Giorgos "Dogtooth" Lanthimos returns with Alps … In a month … Michael Haneke on love and mortality in Amour… The sun sets on Twilight in Breaking Dawn Part 2 …
